The crippled silver albatross
To its destiny is flying
Mayday! Mayday! 
With both it’s engines dying

 There hangs a deathly silence 

An old lady reads her bible
A boy hugs his teddy bear
The captain gives a curse
And two lovers say a prayer

The crippled silver albatross
Very slowly is descending
Mayday! Mayday! 
Disaster is impending

There hangs a deathly silence 

Wide eyes peer through windows
Apprehension starts to grow
They can see the sparkling ocean
Which awaits them far below
  
The crippled silver albatross
Ever downwards it is gliding
Mayday! Mayday! 
And hopes are fast subsiding 

There hangs a deathly silence 

 The old lady starts to tremble
As the tension starts to rise
The captain says ‘don’t panic’
But defeat shows in his eyes
 
The crippled silver albatross
Over water it is skimming
Mayday! Mayday! 
The cabin lights are dimming

There hangs a deathly silence
 
The boy clings to his teddy 
The two lovers say goodbye
As a girl writes out a note
The hostess starts to cry

The crippled silver albatross
Is making its final call
Mayday! Mayday! 
May God be with us all

 There hangs a deathly silence
----
Black smoke drifts on the water
A note flutters in the air
There’s a Holy Bible bobbing
Near a ringlet of blonde hair 
Two glassy eyes are staring
From a soggy teddy bear
At a little book of secrets
That two lovers used to share 
The remnants of existence
The flotsam of despair

There hangs a deathly silence ﻿

+Jagi Raoh You're not up to date on this story. The satellite data shows 
that the plane went south and finished transmitting about 1500 miles off 
Perth Australia. The fuel on board was diminishing and there is no land or 
anywhere for the plane to land in that area. The people are gone. It's not 
fair or reasonable to suggest otherwise. It is best to accommodate the 
actuality. Also the search has not just begun. The search has been on since 
the disappearance was known. Many people have had unrealistic expectations 
of finding the plane immediately and of finding it in a huge expanse of 
water and also of having an explanation, within days, of exactly what 
happened. We are mortals, not gods, and are not omniscient and omnipotent. 
Accidents and deliberate acts happen and ordinary lives are lost. It's just 
part of human activity. Let's just be thankful for the fact that air travel 
is probably the safest mode available and that modern technology has helped 
us to make it that way and also aids us when losses occur.

transponders, so by the time the pilots were able to communicate it was no 
longer possible. Also, there was a mumbling heard by Vietnam ATC, which

enough in the cockpit panels to destroy all methods of control/input from 
the crew, yet since this is a very computerized airplane, the internal

the plane could continue flying on it's (altered) path for hours until it 
ran out of fuel, all while those aboard had zero control of the plane. And 
about the jump to high altitude, this could have been done to reduce the 
oxygen supply to the fire. And the abrupt descent could have been to combat 
the smoke filling the cockpit so that the pilots could breath (oxygen masks 
can't be used during a fire.. they would only add fuel to the fire).  ﻿
